The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Honestly, I appreciate the constraints put on Mary and Luke by the software, but it would have been so much more helpful to have lab style classes where we worked through problem sets in Woodstock so that we could get more hands-on time with the software and a better sense of its utility. Some of the guest lecturers were a little dry and, without the software in front of us, it's hard to apply and retain what they're introducing.
As and auditor, I am not the best person to comment in detail. I do think the materials are very valuable, and I am thinking of taking the course for credit in the future.

The course was designed around several practitioners coming in to teach us about their experience with the subject matter. Unfortunately, this led to some inconsistency with the assignments, as well as some issues with instructors not being able to make it to class.

This course was very frustrating and a poor use of my limited time as a student at FES. Learning the application of growth and yield modeling software is an important part of my interest in a career in forest management. I was very interested in applying principles I learned from Forest Ecosystem Finance, to the modeling software being taught in this course, however do not think that the course was organized well or taught effectively. I did not accomplish my goals for the course, and don't think most people did. About half of our assignments were canceled, either because they were poorly produced or no students understand the material. The class was only half a semester, and there were 2-3 classes that were just outright canceled, thus vastly limiting my availability to learn the material. The material covered was redundant and very broad, not actually training me in any concrete skills of anything. Overall, this is a very important part of an MF curriculum, but the way it was formatted and taught was incredibly ineffective. I now have a very surface level understanding of the concepts, but nothing more. Honestly, I probably could have gained this from reading a short book instead. My recommendation is to hire someone on who can teach the course once a week that has experience in a university setting with teaching and using growth and yield modeling software. If taught this way, with a strong lab component, the class should be made into a full 3 credit full semester course.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Conservation Fund lectures.
Access to valuable programs, people and procedures.
Meeting practitioners and seeing real world application of forest modeling.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: See note above about getting more time with Woodstock.
Course is very work-heavy for two credits in half a semester. Some of the programs did not work or did not work well. Better documentation is needed -- for the programs.
Consistency in level of instruction and homework assignments. A dedicated instructor who has time to devote to the structure of the course.
Having the computer programs up and running prior to the start of the course.
Course would be improved by Consolidation of teaching to one professor. It's time for yale to hire someone with expertise in growth and yield

The course design is disappointing. Use of software like FVS and Woodstok should not be through guest lecturers. There needs to be more consistency in the material being presented for homework. When a whole assignment gets scrapped from a half-semester course, its affects the learning outcomes adversely.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This is a great course to have to compliment the MF degree, it just needed to include more time with the software. I have greater understanding of the issues around G&Y, but not necessarily greater skill.
This course is very important to the forestry program and should be expanded to a three credit course that covers more.
Growth and yield is a necessary part of forestry, regardless of the scale of management post-yale. This course needs to be improved and offered every year!

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To enhance my understanding of, and familiarity with, growth and yield models used by future employers.
Valuable information.
This course was necessary for my program of study and a course of interest.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Not really. See comments above.
I did not learn as much as I had hoped to in this course.
No
Not at all.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Rather reconsider because it did not match up to the expectations it could have delivered.

Be prepared to hit the ground running. Make room in your schedule. Stay ahead of the curve on work. Work with others. Ask questions, and ask for help. And be prepared to learn a lot of very valuable material.
I imagine the course will continue to evolve in the future. I would advise students wanting to take the course to check in about the structure of the course whenever they choose to take it.
Make sure you have a solid grasp of excel, be patient with professors; this course is developing
If the course format continues to be the same i.e delivered through guest lectures, perhaps you would benefit from a course like silviculture taught by prof. mark ashton.
